ground_truth: Jane picks up the address book, frowning, and we're across from her window, looking in as she speaks into the phone, though we can't hear her. Meanwhile, Barbara Fitts stands at the stove, flipping bacon strips mechanically with her eyes focused elsewhere. She is at least ten years younger than her husband and is pretty in a June Cleaver-ish way. Ricky enters and startles Barbara, who turns to him as she attempts to serve him bacon. Ricky serves himself scrambled eggs from another pan, then joins his father at the table. The Colonel sits at a dinette reading The Wall Street Journal, and then he and Barbara look at each other, alarmed. The Colonel heads toward the living room, a little puffed up, and opens the front door to reveal the two Jims. Jim #1 holds out a basket filled with flowers, vegetables, and a small white cardboard box tied with raffia, as the Colonel stares at them, suspicious. The Jims look at each other, then back at the Colonel, who looks at them confused, but then it dawns on him. The Colonel drives, staring darkly at the road ahead, with Ricky in the passenger seat using a calculator and jotting numbers down in a notebook. The Colonel looks at Ricky sharply, and his eyes flash angrily. After a beat, as Ricky continues his calculations, he realizes a response is expected from him, so he sighs and then looks at his father. The Colonel is taken aback but quickly covers, and Ricky goes back to his calculations, totaling two columns of numbers. Jane and Angela are standing with two other teenage girls, who then move away from them. The Colonel's Ford Explorer pulls up, and Ricky gets out. Angela stares at Jane, then her mouth widens into a smile as Jane suddenly finds Ricky standing in front of her, looking at her intently with his eyes searching hers. Jane is unnerved and has to look away, so Ricky smiles and walks off while Angela shoots a wide-eyed look at Jane, who ignores it. The Colonel and Barbara are seated on a couch, watching television, and while the Colonel is smiling, enjoying the show, Barbara just stares. The Colonel chuckles at a joke and startles her, as the three of them stare at the TV like strangers in an airport. We follow them as they pass a sign, and inside the ballroom, well-dressed real estate professionals stand in clumps, chatting, while catering waiters serve hors d'oeuvres. Carolyn's jaw tightens, then she drags Lester toward a silver-haired man and his much younger wife, whom we recognize as Buddy Kane, the Real Estate King. Carolyn quickly joins in a little too loudly, smiling her most winning smile at him.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Jane lifts up the directory, scowling, and we're opposite from her casement, gazing in as she articulates into the receiver, although we can't perceive her. Meanwhile, Barbara Fitts stands at the range, turning pork belly segments mechanically with her eyes concentrated elsewhere. She is at least ten years junior than her spouse and is attractive in a June Cleaver-ish manner. Ricky arrives and surprises Barbara, who turns to him as she endeavors to serve him bacon. Ricky serves himself scrambled eggs from another skillet, then unites with his father at the table. The Colonel sits at a dinette perusing The Wall Street Journal, and then he and Barbara gaze at each other, alarmed. The Colonel heads toward the parlor, a little puffed up, and opens the front entrance to reveal the two Jims. Jim #1 extends a basket filled with blossoms, produce, and a small white carton tied with raffia, as the Colonel gazes at them, distrustful. The Jims glance at each other, then back at the Colonel, who looks at them confused, but then it dawns on him. The Colonel drives, staring darkly at the route ahead, with Ricky in the passenger position using a calculator and jotting digits down in a notepad. The Colonel gazes at Ricky sharply, and his eyes flash furiously. After a moment, as Ricky continues his computations, he realizes a response is expected from him, so he exhales and then gazes at his father. The Colonel is taken aback but rapidly covers, and Ricky returns to his computations, totaling two columns of numbers. Jane and Angela are standing with two other adolescent girls, who then move away from them. The Colonel's Ford Explorer arrives, and Ricky disembarks. Angela gazes at Jane, then her mouth expands into a grin as Jane suddenly discovers Ricky standing in front of her, gazing at her intently with his eyes searching hers. Jane is unnerved and has to look away, so Ricky grins and walks off while Angela shoots a wide-eyed glance at Jane, who ignores it. The Colonel and Barbara are seated on a divan, watching television, and while the Colonel is smiling, enjoying the show, Barbara just gazes. The Colonel chuckles at a jest and startles her, as the three of them gaze at the TV like strangers in a terminal. We follow them as they pass a sign, and inside the ballroom, well-dressed property professionals stand in clusters, conversing, while catering waiters serve appetizers. Carolyn's jaw tightens, then she drags Lester toward a silver-haired man and his much younger wife, whom we recognize as Buddy Kane, the Real Estate King. Carolyn quickly joins in a little too loudly, smiling her most winning grin at him.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Jane picks up the address book, frowning, while we're across from her window, watching her speak into the phone, though we can't hear her. Nearby, Barbara Fitts is at the stove, flipping bacon absentmindedly. Younger than her husband, she's attractive in a June Cleaver-ish way. Ricky enters, startling Barbara as she serves bacon. He grabs scrambled eggs from another pan, then sits with his father, the Colonel, who reads The Wall Street Journal. Alarmed, the Colonel and Barbara exchange glances. He opens the front door to the two Jims. Jim #1 offers a basket filled with flowers, vegetables, and a small white box tied with raffia, as the Colonel eyes them suspiciously. The Jims exchange glances before the Colonel understands. The Colonel drives, focused on the road, while Ricky uses a calculator and notebook. The Colonel glares, expecting a response, so Ricky sighs and looks at him. The Colonel, surprised, quickly masks it, and Ricky resumes totaling numbers. Jane and Angela stand with two other girls, who leave. The Colonel's Ford Explorer arrives, and Ricky exits. Angela smiles widely at Jane as Ricky gazes at her intensely. Unsettled, Jane looks away, and Ricky smiles, walking off. Angela gives Jane a wide-eyed look, which she ignores. The Colonel and Barbara, seated on a couch, watch TV; while the Colonel laughs, Barbara just stares. He chuckles at a joke, startling her. We follow them past a sign into a ballroom where well-dressed real estate professionals gather, chatting as waiters serve hors d'oeuvres. Carolyn's jaw tightens, dragging Lester to Buddy Kane, the Real Estate King, and his much younger wife, joining them loudly with a winning smile.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Jane frowns at an address book while speaking inaudibly on the phone. Barbara Fitts, younger and June Cleaver-like, flips bacon at the stove. Ricky startles her, serves himself eggs, and joins his father at the table. The Colonel reads The Wall Street Journal, then looks alarmed. Answering the door, he finds the two Jims with a basket. Suspicious, he drives with Ricky, who is calculating in a notebook. The Colonel waits angrily for Ricky's response; Ricky sighs and meets his father's gaze. Jane and Angela stand with friends. Ricky arrives, exchanges intense glances with Jane, unnerving her. Angela notices, but Jane ignores it. The Colonel and Barbara watch TV, the Colonel enjoying while Barbara stares. They attend an event where real estate professionals mingle. Carolyn pulls Lester to greet Buddy Kane, the Real Estate King, with an overenthusiastic smile.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Jane, with a furrowed brow, carefully picks up the small address book, and from where we are positioned across from her window, we observe her as she speaks into the phone, although the words she utters remain inaudible to us. Meanwhile, Barbara Fitts is absorbed in her own task, standing over the stove where she mechanically flips sizzling strips of bacon, her eyes focused intently on something far removed from her immediate surroundings. Barbara, who appears to be at least a decade younger than her husband, possesses a beauty that could be described as reminiscent of June Cleaver. Suddenly, Ricky makes his entrance, which causes Barbara to jump slightly as she turns her attention to him while attempting to serve him the bacon she has just prepared. Ricky, however, opts to help himself to some scrambled eggs from another waiting pan before he joins his father at the dining table. The Colonel, engrossed in reading The Wall Street Journal, sits at a small dinette, and soon both he and Barbara exchange alarmed glances. The Colonel, puffed up with a sense of purpose, strides toward the living room and opens the front door. There, standing outside, are the two Jims, one of whom, Jim #1, extends a basket overflowing with an assortment of fresh flowers, vegetables, and a small white cardboard box tied neatly with raffia. The Colonel eyes them with a mix of suspicion and curiosity. The Jims exchange quick glances with each other and then direct their focus back on the Colonel, whose expression reveals a moment of confusion before realization dawns upon him. As the Colonel drives down the road, a brooding expression darkening his features, Ricky sits beside him in the passenger seat, engrossed in using a calculator while diligently jotting down figures in a notebook. A tense silence hangs in the air, broken only by the Colonel's sharp glance at Ricky, which is charged with barely contained anger. A few moments later, sensing that a response is anticipated, Ricky lets out a sigh, redirecting his attention toward his father. The Colonel, momentarily caught off guard by this interaction, quickly regains his composure as Ricky resumes his task of totaling two painstakingly calculated columns of numbers. In another scene, Jane and Angela are positioned with two other teenage girls, who eventually drift away from them. The arrival of the Colonel's Ford Explorer signals a change, and Ricky emerges from the vehicle. Angela's gaze fixes on Jane, which is soon followed by a widening smile as Jane finds herself confronted by Ricky, who stands before her, his eyes locked onto hers with an intensity that leaves Jane feeling unsettled, prompting her to avert her gaze. Ricky, sensing her discomfort, allows a smile to play across his lips and then casually walks away while Angela casts a wide-eyed look toward Jane, who pointedly chooses to ignore it. Meanwhile, the Colonel and Barbara find themselves seated together on a couch, seemingly absorbed in watching television. The Colonel appears to be enjoying the program, evident in his occasional smiles, while Barbara merely stares blankly at the screen. The Colonel lets out a chuckle in response to a joke, momentarily startling Barbara, and it becomes apparent that the three people on the couch are watching the television more like strangers awaiting a flight at an airport terminal. As we continue to follow their interactions, we see them pass by a sign and enter a bustling ballroom where impeccably dressed real estate professionals gather in clusters, engaging in animated conversations, while catering waiters skillfully maneuver through the crowd, offering trays of hors d'oeuvres. Carolyn's jaw tightens noticeably as she pulls Lester toward a distinguished silver-haired man and his considerably younger wife, whom we quickly recognize as the formidable Buddy Kane, often referred to as the Real Estate King. With renewed enthusiasm, Carolyn eagerly inserts herself into their conversation, her voice rising slightly in volume, all the while wearing her most radiant and charming smile.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Jane, wearing an expression of intense concentration marked by her furrowed brow, delicately picks up the small, well-worn address book. From our vantage point, positioned directly across from her window, we can see her as she speaks into the phone. However, the precise words she articulates remain entirely inaudible to us. In the meantime, Barbara Fitts is deeply engrossed in her own activity. She stands over the stove, where she methodically flips sizzling strips of bacon, her eyes focused intently on something existing far beyond her immediate surroundings. Barbara, who seems to be at least a decade younger than her husband, possesses a beauty that could accurately be described as reminiscent of the idealized June Cleaver. Suddenly, Ricky makes his entrance, and it causes Barbara to jump ever so slightly. She quickly redirects her attention toward him while simultaneously attempting to serve him the freshly prepared bacon. Ricky, however, chooses to help himself to some scrambled eggs from another pan waiting on the stove before he proceeds to join his father at the dining table. The Colonel, deeply engrossed in the pages of The Wall Street Journal, sits at a small, cozy dinette, and soon, both he and Barbara exchange glances filled with alarm. The Colonel, puffed up with a palpable sense of purpose, strides confidently toward the living room and opens the front door. Standing outside are the two Jims, and Jim #1 extends a basket brimming with an appealing assortment of fresh flowers, vibrant vegetables, and a small white cardboard box, which is neatly tied with natural raffia. The Colonel regards them both with a mixture of suspicion and curiosity. The Jims exchange quick glances with one another before redirecting their attention back to the Colonel, whose expression reveals a fleeting moment of confusion before a realization finally dawns upon him. As the Colonel drives down the road, his features darkened by a brooding expression, Ricky sits beside him in the passenger seat, engrossed in using a calculator while meticulously jotting down figures in a notebook. A tense and uncomfortable silence hangs heavily in the air, broken only by the Colonel's sharp and penetrating glance at Ricky, which is charged with barely contained anger. A few moments later, sensing that a response is expected, Ricky releases a sigh and redirects his attention toward his father. The Colonel, momentarily caught off guard by this interaction, quickly regains his composure as Ricky resumes the task of totaling two painstakingly calculated columns of numbers. In another scene entirely, Jane and Angela are positioned with two other teenage girls, who eventually drift away from their group. The arrival of the Colonel's Ford Explorer signals a change in the atmosphere, and Ricky emerges from the vehicle with a casual grace. Angela's gaze fixes intently on Jane, which is soon followed by a smile that widens as Jane finds herself confronted by Ricky, who stands confidently before her, his eyes locked onto hers with an intensity that leaves Jane feeling notably unsettled, prompting her to avert her gaze. Ricky, noticing her discomfort, allows a smile to play across his lips before casually walking away while Angela casts a wide-eyed, questioning look toward Jane, who makes a deliberate choice to ignore it. Meanwhile, the Colonel and Barbara find themselves seated together on a couch, seemingly absorbed in watching television. The Colonel appears to be enjoying the program, as evidenced by his occasional smiles, while Barbara merely stares blankly at the screen with little interest. The Colonel lets out a chuckle in response to a joke, momentarily startling Barbara, and it becomes abundantly clear that the three people on the couch are watching the television much like strangers might while awaiting a flight at an airport terminal. As we continue to follow their interactions, we see them pass by a sign and enter a bustling ballroom, where impeccably dressed real estate professionals gather in clusters, engaging in animated and lively conversations. Catering waiters skillfully maneuver through the crowd, offering trays filled with tempting hors d'oeuvres. Carolyn's jaw noticeably tightens as she purposefully pulls Lester toward a distinguished silver-haired man and his considerably younger wife, whom we quickly recognize as the formidable Buddy Kane, who is frequently referred to as the Real Estate King. With renewed enthusiasm and determination, Carolyn eagerly inserts herself into their ongoing conversation. Her voice rises slightly in volume, all the while she wears her most radiant and charming smile.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Jane, furrowing her brow in concentration, picks up the address book with her fingers curling around its edges, and we find ourselves observing her through the window as she presses the phone to her ear, speaking words we cannot hear. Simultaneously, Barbara Fitts stands by the stove, her hands moving methodically as she flips strips of bacon, her eyes staring blankly ahead, seemingly lost in thought. She appears younger than her husband by at least a decade and carries a traditional, June Cleaver-like prettiness. Suddenly, Ricky enters the kitchen, causing Barbara to jump slightly; she turns towards him with an attempt to serve bacon in hand, but Ricky bypasses her and helps himself to scrambled eggs from a different pan before moving to join his father at the table. The Colonel is seated at the dinette, absorbed in reading The Wall Street Journal, when he and Barbara exchange a startled glance, and the Colonel rises with a sense of purpose, moving toward the living room. He opens the front door, standing a bit puffed up, to find the two Jims standing there. Jim #1 extends a basket brimming with flowers, vegetables, and a small white cardboard box tied with raffia, as the Colonel fixes them with a suspicious stare. Exchanging silent looks, the Jims turn their gaze back to the Colonel, who remains confused until a flicker of realization crosses his face. The scene shifts with the Colonel driving, his eyes fixed intently on the road, his expression dark, while Ricky sits in the passenger seat, his fingers deftly pressing the calculator buttons and jotting down numbers in a notebook. The Colonel casts a sharp, angry glance at Ricky, prompting Ricky, who continues his calculations, to become aware that a response from him is anticipated. He emits a weary sigh and turns his gaze toward his father; the Colonel momentarily appears taken aback but swiftly regains composure, and Ricky resumes his task of summing two columns of numbers. In another setting, Jane and Angela are standing with two other teenage girls, who then drift away. The Colonel's Ford Explorer pulls to a halt, and Ricky exits the vehicle. Angela's gaze locks onto Jane, her smile broadening as Ricky unexpectedly appears before Jane, scrutinizing her intently with his eyes delving into hers. Jane, feeling uneasy, averts her gaze, prompting Ricky to smile softly and walk away, while Angela casts a wide-eyed look at Jane, who chooses to disregard it. Meanwhile, the Colonel and Barbara are positioned on a couch, their attention on the television; the Colonel is grinning and enjoying the show, while Barbara merely stares blankly. The Colonel's laughter at a joke startles her, and the three of them continue watching the television much like strangers sitting together at an airport terminal. Transitioning to another locale, we trail them as they pass a sign, revealing the interior of a ballroom filled with well-dressed real estate professionals grouped in clusters, engaged in conversation as catering waiters circulate with trays of hors d'oeuvres. Here, Carolyn visibly tightens her jaw before pulling Lester toward a silver-haired man accompanied by his notably younger wife, whom we identify as Buddy Kane, the Real Estate King. Carolyn approaches with a burst of volume, her voice a tad too loud, while flashing her most charming smile at him.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description:
Jane studies the address book with a frown while speaking on the phone, her window separating us from hearing her words. Nearby, Barbara Fitts, younger than her husband and reminiscent of June Cleaver, mechanically tends to bacon at the stove, distracted, until Ricky enters and startles her. She then turns to serve him bacon, but Ricky helps himself to scrambled eggs and joins his father, the Colonel, who is immersed in The Wall Street Journal. Upon exchanging alarmed looks, the Colonel heads to the living room, opens the front door, and confronts the two Jims. Jim #1 offers a basket of flowers, vegetables, and a small box, leading the suspicious Colonel through a moment of realization. 

While driving, the Colonel glares at the road, with Ricky beside him, absorbed in calculations. Sensing his father's expectation, Ricky pauses his work, sighs, and acknowledges him, leaving the Colonel momentarily taken aback, yet quickly composed. Later, Jane and Angela stand with peers, who eventually depart as Ricky arrives, capturing Jane's attention. Angela grins, and Jane, unnerved by Ricky's intent gaze, looks away as he departs, leaving Angela to exchange a wide-eyed glance with Jane, who ignores it.

Meanwhile, at home, the Colonel and Barbara watch TV, though only he is entertained while she remains detached. In another setting, we see well-dressed real estate professionals mingling in a ballroom as waiters circulate with hors d'oeuvres. Carolyn's demeanor shifts as she leads Lester toward Buddy Kane, the Real Estate King, and his much younger wife, where Carolyn joins the conversation with an overly enthusiastic charm.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Jane picks up the address book, frowning, and we're across from her window, looking in as she speaks into the phone, though we can't hear her. Address books, once a household staple before the digital era, often held personal connections and contacts. Meanwhile, Barbara Fitts stands at the stove, a modern gas range that replaced her old electric model last year, flipping bacon strips mechanically with her eyes focused elsewhere. She is at least ten years younger than her husband and is pretty in a June Cleaver-ish way, reminiscent of the iconic 1950s television housewife from "Leave It to Beaver." Ricky enters, home from school early due to a pep rally, and startles Barbara, who turns to him as she attempts to serve him bacon. Ricky serves himself scrambled eggs from another pan, which he had perfected to his taste during culinary class, then joins his father at the table. The Colonel sits at a dinette reading The Wall Street Journal, a leading international business-focused newspaper, and then he and Barbara look at each other, alarmed. The Colonel heads toward the living room, a little puffed up with the confidence of one who served in the military, and opens the front door to reveal the two Jims. Jim #1 holds out a basket filled with flowers, vegetables, and a small white cardboard box tied with raffia, a natural fiber sourced from palm trees, as the Colonel stares at them, suspicious. The Jims look at each other, then back at the Colonel, who looks at them confused, but then it dawns on him, a realization of past interactions. The Colonel drives, a former Marine, staring darkly at the road ahead, with Ricky in the passenger seat using a calculator and jotting numbers down in a notebook for his upcoming math test. The Colonel looks at Ricky sharply, and his eyes flash angrily. After a beat, as Ricky continues his calculations, he realizes a response is expected from him, so he sighs and then looks at his father. The Colonel is taken aback but quickly covers, maintaining his stoic facade, and Ricky goes back to his calculations, totaling two columns of numbers vital for his algebra homework. Jane and Angela are standing with two other teenage girls, who then move away from them. The Colonel's Ford Explorer, a popular SUV model for families, pulls up, and Ricky gets out. Angela stares at Jane, then her mouth widens into a smile as Jane suddenly finds Ricky standing in front of her, looking at her intently with his eyes searching hers. Jane is unnerved and has to look away, so Ricky smiles and walks off while Angela shoots a wide-eyed look at Jane, who ignores it, pretending nothing happened. The Colonel and Barbara are seated on a couch, a plush piece of furniture they bought at a summer sale, watching television, and while the Colonel is smiling, enjoying the show with the lightheartedness of a sitcom, Barbara just stares. The Colonel chuckles at a joke and startles her, as the three of them stare at the TV like strangers in an airport, surrounded by unfamiliarity. We follow them as they pass a sign directing guests to the ballroom, and inside the ballroom, well-dressed real estate professionals stand in clumps, chatting, a scene reminiscent of a business networking event, while catering waiters serve hors d'oeuvres like miniature quiches and smoked salmon canapés. Carolyn's jaw tightens, then she drags Lester toward a silver-haired man and his much younger wife, whom we recognize as Buddy Kane, the Real Estate King, noted for his numerous best-selling books on property management. Carolyn quickly joins in a little too loudly, smiling her most winning smile at him, hoping to make a lasting impression.

Meanwhile Barbara Fitts stands at the stove flipping bacon strips mechanically with her eyes focused elsewhere. She is at least ten years younger than her husband and is pretty in a June Cleaverish way. Ricky enters and startles Barbara who turns to him as she attempts to serve him bacon. Ricky serves himself scrambled eggs from another pan then joins his father at the table. The Colonel sits at a dinette reading The Wall Street Journal and then he and Barbara look at each other alarmed. The Colonel heads toward the living room a little puffed up and opens the front door to reveal the two Jims. Jim 1 holds out a basket filled with flowers vegetables and a small white cardboard box tied with raffia as the Colonel stares at them suspicious. The Jims look at each other then back at the Colonel who looks at them confused but then it dawns on him. The Colonel looks at Ricky sharply and his eyes flash angrily. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. After a beat as Ricky continues his calculations he realizes a response is expected from him so he sighs and then looks at his father. The Colonel is taken aback but quickly covers and Ricky goes back to his calculations totaling two columns of numbers. test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Jane examines an address book while talking on the phone, unseen from outside. Barbara Fitts, mechanically cooking bacon, is younger and reminiscent of June Cleaver. Ricky surprises her in the kitchen, serves himself eggs, and joins his father, the Colonel, who reads The Wall Street Journal. Disturbed by something, the Colonel opens the door to find the two Jims offering a basket, which he regards with suspicion. Later, driving with Ricky, the Colonel fixates on the road while Ricky does calculations, feeling pressured by his father's silent expectation. Ricky sighs and acknowledges his father before returning to his work. At school, Jane and Angela stand apart from their peers, watching as Ricky arrives. He focuses intently on Jane, making her uneasy, before walking away as Angela observes. At home, the Colonel and Barbara sit, seemingly disconnected, watching TV—a joke momentarily startles Barbara. The narrative shifts to a ballroom filled with real estate professionals, where Carolyn confidently approaches Buddy Kane, smiling broadly to make an impression.

whom we recognize as Buddy Kane the Real Estate King Ricky serves himself scrambled eggs from another pan then joins his father at the table The Colonel chuckles at a joke and startles her as the three of them stare at the TV like strangers in an airport Jim 1 holds out a basket filled with flowers vegetables and a small white cardboard box tied with raffia as the Colonel stares at them suspicious The Jims look at each other then back at the Colonel who looks at them confused but then it dawns on him Jane picks up the address book frowning and we are across from her window looking in as she speaks into the phone though we cannot hear her Ricky enters and startles Barbara who turns to him as she attempts to serve him bacon waiters serve hors d'oeuvres

test_cases.name: Rotate Half Paragraph
test_cases.description: The Colonel is taken aback but quickly covers and Ricky goes back to his calculations totaling two columns of numbers Jane and Angela are standing with two other teenage girls who then move away from them The Colonel's Ford Explorer pulls up and Ricky gets out Angela stares at Jane then her mouth widens into a smile as Jane suddenly finds Ricky standing in front of her looking at her intently with his eyes searching hers Jane is unnerved and has to look away so Ricky smiles and walks off while Angela shoots a wideeyed look at Jane who ignores it The Colonel and Barbara are seated on a couch watching television and while the Colonel is smiling enjoying the show Barbara just stares The Colonel chuckles at a joke and startles her as the three of them stare at the TV like strangers in an airport We follow them as they pass a sign and inside the ballroom welldressed real estate professionals stand in clumps chatting while catering waiters serve hors d'oeuvres Carolyn's jaw tightens then she drags Lester toward a silverhaired man and his much younger wife whom we recognize as Buddy Kane the Real Estate King Carolyn quickly joins in a little too loudly smiling her most winning smile at him Jane picks up the address book frowning and we are across from her window looking in as she speaks into the phone though we cannot hear her Meanwhile Barbara Fitts stands at the stove flipping bacon strips mechanically with her eyes focused elsewhere She is at least ten years younger than her husband and is pretty in a June Cleaverish way Ricky enters and startles Barbara who turns to him as she attempts to serve him bacon Ricky serves himself scrambled eggs from another pan then joins his father at the table The Colonel sits at a dinette reading The Wall Street Journal and then he and Barbara look at each other alarmed The Colonel heads toward the living room a little puffed up and opens the front door to reveal the two Jims Jim 1 holds out a basket filled with flowers vegetables and a small white cardboard box tied with raffia as the Colonel stares at them suspicious The Jims look at each other then back at the Colonel who looks at them confused but then it dawns on him The Colonel drives staring darkly at the road ahead with Ricky in the passenger seat using a calculator and jotting numbers down in a notebook The Colonel looks at Ricky sharply and his eyes flash angrily After a beat as Ricky continues his calculations he realizes a response is expected from him so he sighs and then looks at his father
